text:
In this video, you’ll see how to set up 
permissions segregation with Grafana Teams.

With this capability, you can address 
security and access control requirements,

simplify user management, and enhance 
productivity by granting users access

to the resources they need to 
perform their roles effectively.

Grafana Teams is a built-in 
access control and team

management system within 
Amazon Managed Grafana.

Amazon Managed Grafana 
supports three user roles for

granting the right permission 
level to an individual user.

If you’re using AWS Single Sign-On 
(SSO), then you can assign the

role permissions directly from the 
Amazon Managed Grafana workspace.
If you’re using SAML authentication,

you’ll define the role in the SAML 
assertion mapping attributes.
In this video, we’ll authenticate using AWS SSO.

This is a Grafana workspace that’s 
already configured to ingest data

from various AWS resources and 
visualize it through dashboards.
Before we begin, let’s view the

users and groups that have been 
assigned access to this workspace.

Each user and group was assigned to one of 
three user types: Admin, Editor, or Viewer.

These types will allow us to grant 
different role permissions in Grafana Teams.

Now, let’s sign in to Amazon Managed Grafana 
as an admin user and create a Grafana Team.

With Grafana Teams, we can manage 
permissions for users who have
common dashboard and permission needs.
This team will be for editors.
Let’s add some members.

We can select from the users 
assigned to our Grafana workspace.
We’ll add the two editors.

On the Teams page, we can see that the 
GrafanaEditors team has two members.

Next, we’ll select a data source and 
grant this team permission to access it.
Specifically, we’ll grant the team permission to

query data from the US East 
Region in Amazon CloudWatch.
The permission was added successfully.

Next, let’s grant the team permission to 
edit dashboards saved to the Editor folder.

There are two folders here, but we’ll only 
grant permissions for the Editor folder.
The permissions have been updated.

Now let’s sign out and then 
sign in using an editor account.
Let’s go to Dashboards.

Notice that we only have 
access to the Editor folder.
Let’s view the dashboard.

Since we are a member of the 
GrafanaEditors team in this account,
we should be able to edit the dashboard.
Let’s remove this panel and save our changes.
The dashboard saved successfully.

You’ve just seen how to set up 
permissions segregation with Grafana Teams.

You can learn more about this topic in
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it’s your turn to try.
